intro: Ulmus macrocarpa var. mandshurica, commonly known as the Manchurian elm, is a deciduous tree native to northeastern China and parts of Russia. It is characterized by its broad, heart-shaped leaves that are typically 5–10 cm in length. The tree produces small, spherical fruits that are clustered in groups of two to four. It prefers well-drained soils and full sun, often growing in temperate climates. Due to its ornamental value and adaptability, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens and parks.
